node.title: Frustration Over a Stalled Bill
node.alt: A semiconductor at a research facility in Beijing.
node.description: Democrats favor federal support for scientific research. Why canâ€™t they agree?
node.content: ["In its early years, the semiconductor industry did not have many customers. Few businesses in the 1950s could make use of the expensive new devices that allowed computers to function. But one organization could: the federal government.", "The first shipment from Fairchild Semiconductor \u2014 the company that helped create Silicon Valley \u2014 was for the computers inside the Air Force\u2019s B-70 bomber. The Minuteman missile soon needed semiconductors too, as did other Cold War weapons systems and NASA equipment. \u201cIt was government that created the large demand that facilitated mass production\u201d of semiconductors, as the author Fred Kaplan wrote in Slate.", "This story is common across the history of technological progress. Individual businesses often can\u2019t afford to spend much on basic scientific research. Its outcomes are too uncertain for any one company to know which research will be profitable. In many cases, research that seems likely to benefit one industry ends up benefiting a different one.", "Only the federal government tends to have the resources to make these investments. After it does, private companies then use its fruits to develop innovative and profitable products, spurring economic growth and tax revenues that comfortably cover the cost of the original research.", "The Defense Department built the original internet \u2014 and Google, Microsoft, Amazon and others expanded it. The National Institutes of Health funded laboratory experiments \u2014 and pharmaceutical companies created treatments based on them, including for Covid-19. There are similar stories in energy, automobiles, aviation and other industries.", "In recent decades, however, American investment in research and development has lagged:", "The U.S. now spends a smaller share of national output on research and development than many other countries. China is notably ambitious in this area, essentially copying the American strategy for building a strong economy, even as the U.S. has abandoned that strategy.", "In The Wall Street Journal this week, Graham Allison, a Harvard professor, and Eric Schmidt, the former C.E.O. of Google, wrote, \u201cIn each of the foundational technologies of the 21st century \u2014 artificial intelligence, semiconductors, 5G wireless, quantum information science, biotechnology and green energy \u2014 China could soon be the global leader.\u201d", "The semiconductor industry is a particularly good case study. U.S. companies like Fairchild and Texas Instruments initially dominated, followed in later decades by Intel. But the U.S. semiconductor industry has fallen behind (as Thomas Friedman has explained). U.S. companies make about 12 percent of the world\u2019s semiconductors, down from 37 percent in 1990.", "\u201cRight now, America makes zero percent of the most sophisticated chips,\u201d Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, told me recently. \u201cThat\u2019s a vulnerability.\u201d Taiwanese companies like TSMC manufacture many of the most sophisticated chips, which means that a disruption there \u2014 hardly out of the question, given China\u2019s aggression \u2014 could disrupt the global economy.", "\u201cWe need to make more chips in America,\u201d Raimondo said.", "In June, the Senate passed a bill that would help make that happen. It would spend almost $250 billion over five years on research and development, including $52 billion for semiconductor makers. The main purpose is to keep the U.S. from falling behind China.", "Overall, the bill would increase federal research and development spending by more than 30 percent. It passed along bipartisan lines, 68 to 32, and President Biden supports it.", "But the House has not yet passed a version of it and appears unlikely to do so before recessing for the year. House Democrats have specific concerns about the Senate bill, as The Times\u2019s Catie Edmondson has reported. Among them: whether it spends enough money on early-stage research \u2014 and too much money on de facto subsidies for private companies like Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos\u2019 space company.", "These are reasonable questions to raise. Still, many economists, governors and industry executives are disappointed that the House and the Senate have not figured out how to resolve relatively minor differences and expand federal support of scientific research. \u201cCandidly, it should have passed the House a while back,\u201d Representative Ro Khanna, a California Democrat, said this week. \u201cIt\u2019s been too slow.\u201d", "My colleague Catie told me: \u201cSemiconductor companies have been basically tearing their hair out over this delay. They felt it was a huge triumph when it passed the Senate earlier this year and have been fairly dismayed by how long it\u2019s taking to actually get the money in their pockets.\u201d", "Congressional dysfunction in recent years has more often been caused by Republicans than by Democrats. When Republicans controlled Congress, they disagreed on major issues (like health care, immigration and Covid), and congressional Republicans have reflexively opposed many proposals from Democratic presidents.", "But the delays in passing the research bill \u2014 and its potential defeat \u2014 stem more from Democratic infighting. Even though Democrats control the House, albeit narrowly, and the Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill months ago, it still has not made it to Biden\u2019s desk. America\u2019s global rivals are no doubt cheered by the dysfunction.", "Without legislation to address gun violence, there\u2019s only so much teachers can do, Sarah Lerner argues.", "It\u2019s OK to be furious at the unvaccinated, Charles Blow writes.", "Fortify nursing homes against Omicron, says Zeynep Tufekci.", "Wildlife: Manatees are in crisis.", "Pop: \u201cDirty\u201d soda shops are spreading.", "Fame: Social media fandom doesn\u2019t always sell a lot of books. Ask Billie Eilish.", "Ask Well: Is Gluten-free bread healthier?", "Advice from Wirecutter: Back up and secure your digital life.", "Lives Lived: Greg Tate exploded onto the New York cultural scene in the early 1980s, becoming The Village Voice\u2019s pre-eminent writer on Black music and art and one of the city\u2019s leading critics. He died at 64.", "The onslaught of best-of lists in December can be overwhelming. Consider this a guide to the guides.", "For the music nerds, Pitchfork unveiled its annual list of best songs. It pairs well with The Times\u2019s wide-ranging picks for best albums of the year. Each of our pop music critics made lists, and two albums overlapped on all of them: Tyler, the Creator\u2019s \u201cCall Me if You Get Lost\u201d and Olivia Rodrigo\u2019s \u201cSour.\u201d", "In the Book Review\u2019s 10 best fiction and nonfiction titles, there are ruminations on race in America and generation-spanning sagas. Craving some art? Of the year\u2019s many ambitious exhibitions, two consistent themes were the African-American South and climate change. In New York\u2019s Madison Square Park, Maya Lin\u2019s \u201cGhost Forest\u201d contrasted the park\u2019s greenery with a grove of dead, environmentally damaged Atlantic white cedars. Teenagers are repurposing the wood to make boats.", "The return of in-person experiences was another recurring theme: The fall theater season was \u201cas exciting as a child\u2019s first fireworks,\u201d Jesse Green writes, and the ritual of watching movies on a big screen made even the most mediocre movies glorious, Manohla Dargis writes in her list of best films.", "There was also great TV. Many of our critics\u2019 picks covered subjects like class conflict and pandemics. A personal favorite: \u201cReservation Dogs,\u201d a meandering, occasionally surreal comedy about four teens desperate to escape their Oklahoma reservation. It\u2019s full of the kinds of details \u201cthat can only come from loving the thing you want to leave,\u201d James Poniewozik writes.", "Find all of The Times\u2019s best of 2021 lists here. \u2014 Sanam Yar, a Morning writer", "Try making some of The Times\u2019s most popular recipes. This creamy macaroni and cheese came close to taking the year\u2019s top spot.", "Steven Spielberg\u2019s film version of \u201cWest Side Story\u201d feels \u201cbold, surprising and new,\u201d A.O. Scott writes.", "Svalbard, a Norwegian archipelago, is full of ethereal waterfalls.", "The hosts joked about the burning Fox News Christmas tree.", "The pangram from yesterday\u2019s Spelling Bee was laboratory. Here is today\u2019s puzzle \u2014 or you can play online.", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Astonish (five letters).", "If you\u2019re in the mood to play more, find all our games here.", "Thanks for spending part of your morning with The Times. See you tomorrow. \u2014 David", "P.S.
